content.description: Named after the god-awful roar of the off-road terrorists.... This is the easiest of the routes here, but no gimme.  Steep rock leads up and left to an obvious break in the overhang.  Getting up to and clearing the overhang is the physical crux, but then it requires thoughtful, thin, balance moves past the last two clips.
content.protection:
Bolts and shared anchor with

Kawasaki Hood Ornament

.
content.location: This route starts in the corridor @ an oddly  low first bolt on easy terrain.

content.description:
This route climbs easy rock to a ledge below a steep wall split by a thin crack.  Snow Scooter clips the bolts to the right of this crack while

YngYngYng

clips the bolts to the left of the crack. The two routes share some holds in this section.  After climbing to a small roof, you latch a perfect, knob-like chickenhead.  Pulling up onto the ledge above this chickenhead is the crux.  Easier climbing above leads to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the 5th bolted route from the left.  It shares some moves with YNGYNGYNG before breaking off to the right.  Descend from a two bolt anchor shared with Tear it Up!

content.description:
This is currently the second to furthest left bolted route at Scooter Trash Wall.  The route starts in the base of a gully/chasm up a featured face with orange, yellow, and green lichen.

This climb can be a heady lead due to the proximity of the back wall, but the falls are clean. Enjoy sustained crimps, sidepulls, and pinches to the top.

If you want, you can scramble to the top of the back wall and eye all of the moves/holds for the route.

Loud and obnoxious from the start, this route keeps the racket up until you shut the motor off at the anchor.  Continuous crimper edges keep coming the whole way with nice sequences. Be careful not to backslam the opposing wall at the start.
content.location: This is the 1st route left on the Scooter Trash Wall.

content.description: This is a great climb that requires both strength and technique.  Climb vertical rock past two bolts to a stance below the roof.  Clip another bolt here and use whatever strength you have to pull over.  This is the crux.  The face above is where the technique is involved as you climb sequential technical moves to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 or 7 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the third bolted route from the left.  It starts from level ground in the corridor and climbs red, lichen stained rock to a small roof that contains black lichen. Descend from a two bolt anchor shared with

YngYngYng

.
